Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: Management closely monitors break logs because the phone queue remains consistently full.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: A flash-flood warning triggers building alarms as water rises along the block.
Story: The phone in my headset buzzed with another incoming call, the queue never-ending, my break scheduled for five minutes from now. Management’s reminders echoed in my mind—no unscheduled breaks, every minute logged, every absence scrutinized. I glanced at the clock, feeling the pressure to stay put, to keep dialing, to not let the team down. Suddenly, the building’s alarm blared, and a message flashed across my screen: “Flash-flood warning. Evacuate immediately.” I looked out the window and saw water creeping up the street, neighbors scrambling to help each other. As a citizen, I knew I should act—help the elderly woman next door, check on the kids upstairs, follow the evacuation plan. But my supervisor’s voice in my head insisted, “Stay at your station unless on break.” My heart pounded, torn between the duty to my job and the responsibility to my community. I stared at my break log, finger hovering over the button, caught in the impossible space between two worlds, each demanding something I couldn’t give to both.
